review_title: Research Institute is Elitist but the Inclusion Networks are Amazing
pros: You can find amazing people to connect with across the organization, particularly through the employee resource groups, known as the Inclusion Networks. Having that community within the organization is crucial, especially if you have any marginalized identities. Being a part of the Inclusion Networks was my favorite benefit. Work life balance is really dependent on what role you have and what department you are in but in general, you are able to have that balance over in the Research Institute. If you are able to take advantage of the benefits offered, you can have a lot of career growth and gain a lot of new skills, including through the Inclusion Networks.
cons: The Research Institute, like many other institutions, is very elitist and you have to fit their mold to be valued and well-respected. The culture is not a place where Black, Indigenous, and other BIPOC folks can truly thrive in unless you assimilate or make sacrifices in how you show up. You’ll also feel discarded if you have any personal struggles because they make you feel like you don’t matter now that you are struggling and unable to work at the capacity as you once were able to. Leaders (Directors, Faculty, and above) are unwilling to change their behaviors and the policies, and are okay with staying in their bubble of privilege. There’s a lot of great people still there, including some leadership, but unfortunately, they aren’t the ones in positions to have the largest impact and as a collective, not enough people speak up for change.

pros: Pay was pretty decent and Company Benefits were good. If you are a workaholic and love the thrill of a hospital workplace learning environment then this would be a good job for you.
cons: Work life balance was extremely poor. Through scheduling and accommodating tech's time off people seemed to think the supervisor showed favoritism and I agree. She didn't seem to care much about me as an individual, I have an autoimmune condition which was still pretty new to me (I didn't know working in the lab would make my condition worse, though it did) and the only accommodation that was made for me was one that was available to everyone already (resting on a stool while working). When trying to reach out to their disability accommodations force I didn't receive a response for a couple months. Their disability protocol was pretty frustrating for me as someone without a visible disability. My body was in so much pain some days I would be in tears at the end of the day and the most that was said to me was I could take a couple minutes to sit down before getting back to my tasks instead of trying to navigate an easier way for me to complete them or having me do tasks that were easier on my body which could have easily been delegated. The manager used me as an example to persuade higher ups to work out a 4-day work weeks (10 hours) instead of 5 day (8 hour shifts) without really talking through if that would be beneficial for me, as I think it was a system she had been trying to get going for awhile. Aside from myself, when talking with my coworkers at the time most people seemed pretty burned out and unable to fully recover from work on their rest days, even when the extra "3-day weekend" was implemented. It was pretty difficult to get to work because there was no on campus parking except for weekends where you would have to pay $5 to park. I walked 30 minutes to the light rail and took the Children's shuttle at the UW light rail station to get to work everyday, so my 10 hour days turned into 12 hours. Overall, it just really wasn't worth it working there. Aside from my own health barriers the job just became my whole life and the weekends were spent recovering from working so that I could work again the next week (coworkers agreed this felt similar to them). One person quit a little before me and another person said they would if they didn't have to support their family with the job. I took a $5/hour pay decrease to leave the work environment I was in and have a better commute. I'm someone who has worked 3 other jobs and stayed at them for between 2-4 years so I am not typically one to jump around. That said, I am surprised I even lasted 6 months there.

pros: Good benefits- 401k, health insurance, non-punitive culture, PTO/sick
cons: SCH has become increasingly corporate during my time there. Nurses are treated like a number, very replaceable despite years of experience. There is minimal effort put towards staff retention and keeping existing staff happy. Upper management gets large bonuses annually, while RN pay does not keep up with cost of living for area. There are many levels of management and so it feels impossible to create meaningful change within the organization. The institution prioritizes families' experience over nurse safety. We are forced to tolerate verbal abuse from parents on a regular basis. Additionally, there is not enough emphasis on skills development and growth of nurses. Instead of developing skills like IV placement, you have to take mandatory training about the latest hospital mantra ("Innovation, Compassion, Equity etc).

job_title: Pediatric Mental Health Specialist I in Seattle, WA

Medical environments such as these can often be plagued by apathy, so it was refreshing to be in a place where staff are doing what they can to fight that.
cons: As a main hub for a several state region, the unit I worked on was often pushed to its limits. Several situations could have been greatly improved with more staff, or quicker transitions for the patients we saw, but neither was always possible, especially within the pandemic. I don't think the management is unaware of these situations, yet faced with difficult choices in a very under-resourced field (behavioral health).

job_title: Patient Account Representative in Seattle, WA
pros:
Despite the recent negative publicity and mistakes the company has made over the past few years, they genuinely care about their patients. I fully believe in their mission and values and I believe that they do as well. Dr. Sperring is a genuinely nice guy that wants to do good for the community and for the organization.

I was paid fairly for the work I did, and the health benefits were decent. Work/life balance is recognized (at least for the department I was in). My coworkers were mostly decent people.
cons:
The Revenue Cycle department is poorly managed, from the top on down. As it seems any time you get a bunch of women working together, there are cliques, favoritism, and in this instance lack of knowledge on how to successfully run a department. 

Management targets people that they feel aren't doing a good job (regardless of whether or not they were) and they make it such a hostile working environment that dealing with it is impossible. There is zero support under certain supervisors, managers and directors. Some supervisors, managers and directors should not even be in their position. Promoting from within should only happen when that promotion is deserved. All in all, you're set up for failure right from the beginning and I wish I had made a different choice. There is little to no equity throughout the department and how each team is treated.

Having said all of that, I still believe in the organization and what it stands for. The problem is that it's too big - you have too many people in important jobs that did not merit those roles, and those people are contributing to the bad morale and bad choices in each team. I'm not sure if I would have had a different experience reporting to a different supervisor but it seems not (based on what I've witnessed personally). Nobody that I've seen is valued for what they contribute, and everybody is harped on for failings - instead of working with us to correct the failings.

review_title: I used to work in a leadership position
pros: Fake values, terrible management and lots of woke culture
cons:
1.	If you are looking for a 9-5 routine job with no potential whatsoever for growth, this will be the best place for you to be.
2.	The Human Resources Department is just a name with people acting as if they know what they are doing. Unfortunately, if you are looking for a professional group of people to go to when you have an issue, you will get squat. Favoritism is the logo in the department, and you will have to know someone personally in the department to make things move forward. I personally had "Normal" performance issues with my staff, and I tried to reach out to HR and I got nothing back. They take ages in responding back, and most of them are on paid or maternity leaves. So, if you have a case or an employee that you worked with one of them on, GOOD LUCK cause you will be following up with a new HR person every time. Very time consuming and unprofessional.
3.	They hire Front End Staff just to fill a place and to have a body. No qualifications or experience review. This will cause you a lot of issues if you are trying to get high production because you will be constantly correcting errors, cleaning messes and imploring HR to intervene.
4.	Some Front End Staff will have personal relationships with managers and even directors. So, if you try to touch any of their beloved staff, they will step on your face. They don't understand the word hierarchy. So, a word of advice, if you want to last, try to kiss the butts of those favored by management even if they are at a lower pay-grade or position than you.
5.	As a leader who worked in several leadership positions in top organizations, I was shocked with the poor management in the department. There was a lack of transparency and almost zero experience from my manager. My manager's opinions and decisions were always clouded with the favorite staff opinions which caused a complete lack of decisiveness. That created a lot of tension between staff because they see some of their co-workers being favored and not held accountable for any errors, while they get crussified whenever they make the slightest mistake. I did my best to stand for the right thing and do what's ethically right, but I was met with my manager reprimanding me to "Tone it down". Before I resigned, all my staff implored me to change my mind, but I did what I had to do to get away from the nightmare.
6.	The Current CEO got a huge backlash because of the bacteria discovered on the walls of the operating rooms. We used to receive ORDERS from our managers to never talk about this to the press (which can be understandable because they don't wanna get sued), but still shows the complete lack of transparency as they used to give us the orders without any explanation or updates. They hold events to preach about equity and open mindedness, but it's all bogus. None of these concepts are actually implemented in the daily operations.
7.	My dept. is currently being sued by a former manager. That manager was exposed to the same level of unprofessionalism and unethical practices, so they decided to sue. I think it's sad but at the same time, Karma was there I guess for me and that manager.
8.	Right now the dept. is struggling with staffing and revenue because of all the poor decisions and the insanely high turnover. 
9.	Discrimination due to religion and color is unfortunately there. Some people in my departement were being bullied or made fun of due to their religion or ethnicity.
10.	The whole organization relies heavily on donations from big names (Like The Costco Family and many others), so you have to understand that this is the main way they make their money. That is why keeping appearances is a huge part of their budget, even if it means that other areas that desperately need reform will be buried and forgotten.
11.	I have to be fair because other depts like Finance have excellent managers and directors, so I'm not generalizing.

review_title: Great People, great mission, great values
pros: Employees in all departments really care about patients and families. The mission feels like a main focus every day, even if you are not patient facing. This makes working together really engaging and meaningful - almost everyone you interact with cares a lot and really wants to be there. Additionally there is a big focus on patient safety and process improvement. Staff of all levels are encouraged and supported to improve how things are done. This lets you learn and grow, and keeps everyone on their toes. It can feel like constant change, but it's usually energizing because you and your peers are helping to drive some/most of the improvements. I think there are good growth opportunities, especially right now as the hospital is growing so much. I was promoted in my department and have been offered ideas and support on how to move up again, even in a different department. I also really appreciate the work-life balance. I plan to stay here!
cons: Sometimes changes are not very well explained or are pushed out very quickly. There can be competing priorities as well. Also at times it feels like we make decisions based on what is best for medical providers, rather than patients. I think all hospitals struggle with that though.

review_title: Unfortunately Low Financial, Professional, and Educational Ceilings as a Workplace
pros: Serving the pediatric patient population and their families is a privilege.  Most clinicians, providers, and employees are amazing, skilled, dedicated people.  I was so proud to serve the patients.  Benefits on par with like organizations.
cons: Lacking leadership at middle-tier-management level, so anticipate drama, potential for negative annual reviews.  The culture is becoming increasingly bent towards administration initiatives at the expense of clinical needs.  Little movement of management across departments leading to exclusive / unilateral decision making domains where a manager can make or break your career.  While they report competitive compensation, it can take a decade to reach the top of your pay scale. For example, a pay scale that starts at $20/hour and tops out at $29/hour reaches $24/hour after 5 years.  HR supports management, not employees-- if you're bullied or disagree with your manager you have no recourse.  Preaches growth, engagement, career and educational opportunities but the emphasis is on administrative growth, not clinical growth, as well as institutional academic snobbery when allowing access to educational opportunities.  A gaping schism between senior management and the worker.

pros: Co workers were intelligent and willing to support you if needed. That is about it though. Otherwise, there are few things good to say about SCH.
cons:
I worked in a department where I watched my manager STEAL expensive equipment and sell it on eBay to pocket the money. He was a raging misogynist and had zero education, training or previous experience.  He was completely incompetent and couldn't perform the most basic functions of the job. None of this was that big of an issue in my daily job functions because he NEVER CAME INTO WORK, and so he never botherd me or my team mate's. We all did our work perfectly without him. Our team would go WEEKS without hearing from him. He would tell others outside of the department he was working from home, but he didn't know how to access our online work sites remotely.

After some time I felt compelled to bring this information to HR because it was becomming a serious ethical issue. Seeing this person steal money and time from sick and dying children. I (and others in the dept) brought this up to upper management and HR. Then our whole team (minus the manager) were investigated for things he had done wrong. We were all reprimanded while he was protected by upper management. HR even agreed that we didn't do anything wrong and that he was the one committing wrong doing, but then told us these are the consequences you face or get out. 

You will also be very under paid and there is little room for career advancement.

review_title: Support Teams not aligned with company "values"
job_title: IS Project Manager in Seattle, WA
pros: The mission, the direct care outcomes, the error prevention philosophy
cons:
The error prevention matrix is not used by IS/IT management. 
Jobs in this department are kept through political means, not merit.  If a manager is afraid of negative outcomes from anyone, they will fire rather than investigate causes and resolve the underlying issues. This results in continued underperformance and reinventing the wheel, so to speak.
Management is weak in applying the same behaviors expected by direct patient care managers when dealing with staff issues.
Technology is redundant, clunky and old from the IT perspective. A lot of money is wasted in just purchasing and supporting physical phones alone. Seems to be someone has an investment in Cisco and not the users. 
As for patient care / records systems, there are 2 (EPIC and CERNER) when only one is necessary. This requires specialists for both systems which is an additional, significant cost to maintain.
IS decisions - or lack thereof - waste money that could be going to kids.
Extremely poor budget planning and commitment when related to construction and renovation projects.

review_title: Not what it used to be
pros: Great mission that most staff are highly committed too. Good benefits, great commute incentives.  Tuition reimbursement can help career growth. Growing company creates opportunity for advancement or to move around. Well known organization, great reputation to work for.
cons: Growth also means It’s not what it used to be, in some ways for the worse. Company is growing faster than front line staff can absorb the work. High level of burnout among many staff as a result. Difficult to get senior leadership suppor to add front line help, expected to absorb all growth through improvement systems only.  Meanwhile, chief officers and senior directors seem to be added more frequently.  Company in many ways takes advantage of staff commitment to mission. Because people want to be there, they get paid “market rate” while expected to have double the productivity. It’s unrealistic to expect to keep only the best without rewarding them for it.

review_title: Opportunity for lasting change and patient support, if management supported us
job_title: Family Services Coordinator in Seattle, WA
pros: Benefits, interactions with patients and families, my direct coworkers, feeling good about the work I did, promise of development opportunities, continuing education classes
cons: Development opportunities granted at management's biased discretion - not on merit of work or ideas, lots of continuous process improvement discussion but projects never stick, when working with internal affinity networks approved projects were undermined at last minute by upper leadership who had not been involved. Overall, the direct work with patients and families is wonderful and fulfilling, if often challenging, and if that is what you want to do at SCH then this is a wonderful department. However, promotions, improvement projects within the organization, and other development opportunities are unequally distributed. Management selects people based on arbitrary traits and targets them for development, ignoring the talents and contributions of those who do not fit that model.

pros: I was very satisfied with my job as an RN at Seattle Children's. They focus on family-centered care, provide excellent training for new and continuing employees, and value patient safety. The research taking place is amazing and makes me want to continue working there. I feel like they also treated the staff well and the people I worked with were generally happy in their positions.
cons: The scheduling and vacation requests were handled differently in each department, and weren't always the best for the nurses. My unit had over 100 nurses, but no more than 4 nurses could request vacation at one time, and it was all based on seniority. The institution had "self-scheduling" but most the time requests weren't honored. Other than minor staffing issues, I don't think there were many "cons" to working at Seattle Children's.

pros:
Pay, Shuttle Service, Friendly Staff

The shuttle service is an awesome benefit, except they’re cutting down the incentive pay for taking the shuttle by a dollar. Most of the staff is generally very happy and friendly, and the atmosphere of the building is happy. It’s the best pay/differentials of most the area hospitals.
cons:
Benefits, No Autonomy, Management

Because it’s a teaching hospital, all orders go through the residents. If you have a great resident that encourages collaboration and discussion, it’s great. However, most orders are “do it because I said so” and there’s not much option to voice your opinion and modify the orders if you believe it’s doing more harm than good. Management (at least middle management) is terrible and unsupportive. The minute they leave bedside, it’s like they forget we’re human. A perfect example is that even though per our union we’re allowed PTO, it’s up to management discretion whether to approve it and in one area, no PTO has been approved in almost a month. Scheduling and vacation requests are also seniority only, so there’s little incentive to stick around if you’re a new grad.

pros: You could not ask for a more fulfilling or higher mission in life, helping sick children, fixing birth defects and deformities, and eradicating childhood diseases.
cons:
Watching the continuous waste of millions of donated dollars by the current upper management that could be going into useful children's health care. 

Seeing major issues (affecting patient care, patient privacy, sexual harassment) being dealt with by paying people off to be quiet and go away, rather than fix the issue. 

Hearing mounting rumors of physicians referring children to general hospitals because of safety issues. 

Instead of paying lip service to your employees, treat them like they actually matter.

pros: Lots of great work in promoting health of children throughout the Seattle area. Changes are easily implemented if you have a good relationship with your supervisor(s). A place where a lot of the people care about the work going on. Transportation benefits are awesome and bonuses are usually tacked on once or twice a year. Looks great on a resume for those who choose not to stay with the company. In addition, the company is quickly growing and evolving so it's great to watch new developments and see how the company expands.
cons: I found it extremely hard to move up in the company. I worked there for over two years and I wasn't even considered to be promoted to a lab tech II position, despite working 6 day weeks, getting various certifications, constantly introducing new kaizen ideas, ect. Pay was okay but not the greatest and health benefits are meh.

review_title: Great Place for Patients, Less Great for Staff

A CIO who has established a faulty infrastructure that does not work and who has no ability to fix it, who promotes a culture of "do not ask do not tell" policy and who have been promoting his friends to director-level management.  An ex-military who wrote an e-mail to the employees with the following: "you are not getting your bonus this year, on the other hand I just made my last alimony payment and am going to celebrate my birthday in tropics"

job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in Seattle, WA
pros: If you love being around children and see the miracles that happen on a daily basis then that is where you will see.
cons: Not enforcing the policies as stated.  PTO is lumped together with holiday pay so you always have to be watching how much time you have available.  The raises don't even cover the cost of living and they are always raising the price you have to pay if you drive to work.  Not everyone lives on a good transit route that lets them get to work without having to leave 2 hrs before your start time.  They say they quest for the best but again it isn't always shown.

pros: The hospital as a whole was very welcoming and seems on the outside to have a positive work environment and genuinely puts the patient needs first. Some departments have a positive  supportive work culture .
cons: The work culture under a new Manager was more about being vetted to be in a sorority group rather than being treated as a  medical Professional. No onboarding /training. It is secretive and vital  instrument data to carry out diagnostic tests is concealed  and used as leverage  to decide weather you succeed or not.Dangerous for patient safety.Slanderous  racist comments about nationality and age. You will be fine here in some departments but in  cardiology it depends whether you are invited into the click and fit a certain profile or not. Y You will  be bullied out if  you don't fit the profile. you are  warned! good luck.

job_title: Family Service Coordinator in Seattle, WA
pros:
Benefits are amazing, I have worked at two other hospitals and they do not compare. 
Staff are beyond friendly and helpful, especially when welcoming someone new.
Management communicates very well and is very supportive. I have had two different supervisors for two different positions and they were constantly checking in on me and made sure I was doing okay, and if I needed anything. I have never had that before, and it was very refreshing. 
Our patients are children, and its so fulfilling knowing that we are making a difference in their lives.
cons:
Nothing. I love it here!

If I had to choose though, probably the commute and traffic. Even then, childrens pays you a bonus everyday if you dont drive in to work by yourself, and if you take a different mode of transportation or carpool.

review_title: Management - Good ole Boys and Girls Club with no skills being a competent manager
pros: Reputation, which now amazes me. Not sure how a hospital with such broken systems and management is able to succeed, however those at the front lines - docs, nurses, etc. are what make the hospital work. They would have to love their job and the mission to stand working there with some of the managers in place.
cons: Poor management. The men and women who make up much of the mgmt team are not there due to stellar mgmt skills ... at all. They are there because of number of years they've worked there. Since Children's does not have a layoff policy, instead of bad performance being weeded out, they remain ... making it miserable for the minority ... the folks who actually care about their jobs and are stellar performers.

review_title: A Highly Structure Enviornment Does Not Mesh with Everyone
job_title: Family Service Coordinator in Seattle, WA
pros: Truly a company where you leave everyday feeling fulfilled.   Seattle Children's is an entire culture centered around children advocacy, not just healthcare.  They provide so many resources to families, and have a strong presences in the community.  It is a fantastic benefits very progressive/forward-thinking company with fantastic benefits offered to their employees.  Overall it is a simple, highly organized business model that stays true to their mission.
cons:
Working in a stressful environment yields a high turnover/burnout rate. 
There is lots of promise but little opportunity to move forward in the company.
Although there is a strong focus on employee satisfaction there is still a lack of staff appreciation from upper management.  It often seems the organization is growing faster than it can compensate.

review_title: Good place to work, growing rapidly, room for improvement
job_title: Clinical Research Associate in Seattle, WA
pros:
-All of my coworkers are awesome. Everyone really cares about the work, and is always professional. No workplace drama.
-Management is great, they really care about employees

review_title: Great place to work, outstanding culture
job_title: Clinical Research Associate I in Seattle, WA
pros: Great people who are dedicated and knowledgeable and are united by their vision and drive to help kids in every way possible. So many people go above and beyond, the interdisciplinary care is spectacular, and I would go there as a patient if I wasn't an adult.
cons: In my experience, issues typical of healthcare including ressure to put in long hours and go above and beyond for every single patient- it sometimes gets emotionally and physically exhausting. But in my opinion it's a small trade off for the wonderful community of supportive staff that's all around you.

pros: I have met some amazing collegues and staff who really want to see this organization improve.  I love working with the families and I love the work that I do.
cons: Most of the great employees I've met are either looking for a job elsewhere or have left.  This is a place where you have no voice and if you do speak up they retaliate or tell you there is the door.  There is a lot of favoritism.  There is no where to get help even if you go to HR they take their sweet old time and dont acomodate meeting with you!

review_title: Started off great, lately it sucks.
pros: Fairly good benefits and an excellent mission.
cons: I started at Children's with such pride in my work and ready to work really hard for the organization. In the last two years, it's been super challenging and I don't feel like I'm appreciated for all the effort and sacrifice I have made for my department. I no longer have good work/life balance. If I'm going to give so much of myself to my work, I'd like to feel like my colleagues and leaders actually appreciate it.

pros: To work at Seattle Children's Hospital is very motivating. Transportation incentive is fantastic, especially since I live up north and bus everyday. The shuttle system is greatly appreciated and offers a quick connection to the hospital from my stop.  Staff for the most part are open to process improvement and it's refreshing that the hospital fosters this type of attitude (both clinical and non-clinical). I was very impressed also with the level of training I received upon hire and the encouragement to seek out further education that would benefit the company.
cons: IT support and tech is lacking. The virtual desktop infrastructure is unreliable at best and extremely frustrating especially for my role. Space is a premium in the older sections of the hospital and offices often have 2 - 4 people sharing. The main cafeteria needs to be updated very badly.

review_title: Love the children, but despise the sorry attempt at leadership/management
pros: If you love kids, this is the place to work.  You have the opportunity to make an impact every day you come to work.  Also, the majority of the employees that work "on the floor" are here for the same reason--they love kids.
cons: Management leans far too heavily on the fact people work there because they love kids--there's absolutely no competition or other pediatric hospitals in the area, so they don't have much competition and can treat employees poorly.  Absolutely no follow-through every year when the annual review takes place--change doesn't occur.

job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in Seattle, WA
pros: Wonderful mission and hard working staff. Good medical benefits, especiallyif you have children.  Opportunity to advance if you move departments frequently. If you stay in the same department, it can take a decade to advance to a new pay grade. The hospital is in very good shape financially, your job is not going anywhere which is a wonderful feeling.
cons: Vacation, sick and holiday time all comes out of PTO. You read that right. If your office is closed on Christmas day, it comes out of your PTO. This policy fosters an environment where people come to work sick because they view their PTO as "vacation" time and don't want to use it on a sick day. Not ideal to have sick people coming to work  in a hospital!

job_title: Family Service Coordinator in Seattle, WA
pros: Great benefits, interesting work, ability to help families and get them the resources they need. The pay is decent for the work that you are doing. i really enjoy working at the hospital. The extra perks that you get are really great- discounts on so many different services. The reputation that the hospital has within the community is also really great.
cons: Parking- like most places in seattle there is not free parking, they also just took away the shuttle from downtown. The hospital is a busy place and there are a lot of providers who are over booked and don't really have capacity for all of the patients that we get. They can be rather overwhelmed

review_title: Great company with some growing pains
pros: Great mission - improving children's health and performing ground breaking research.   Medical and Dental benefits are some of the best coverage at a Seattle employer.   Employees get a transportation bonus for using transit.
cons:
Research staff are siloed with little collaboration between centers
-  Research staff can sometimes feel like an after thought when company wide policies are instituted.
- Research admin staff are pigeon holed to one size fits all cubicles
- Slow to respond ergonomic support for research staff
- Retirement match is low as compared to other employees

pros: I just started there this last week. The environment seems very positive and upbeat. My specific field  is non clinical, they seem to have great employee retention in my department , including some over 30 years. I've already witnessed great communication from management to working employees and vice versa. It seems that they really truly care about feedback to improve. Also the transportation bonus is an excellent benefit.
cons: I have not seen any substantial cons or negatives in my short time so far. You have to pay for parking if you drive in, but the turn around is they pay you if you don't drive.

pros: Everyone who works at Children's believes in the mission of the organization, and works diligently to insure that they receive the best care possible.
cons: There are very few negative aspects of working at Children's. Even when you don't have a good day at work, you can go out the the roof top garden and taken the breath taking views of the PNW or listen to the kids playing in the on-site childcare playground. I think one con is that you have to pay for parking; however, Children's provides many incentives to find alternatives to driving.

review_title: Great benefits but be aware of dysfunctional HR department
job_title: Clinical Research Associate I I in Seattle, WA
pros: The benefits are outstanding, better than most any other company that you will work for. Generous PTO, paid in full Orca pass and money back every time you commute by bus, vanpool etc. Who would not want to work there.
cons: A very dysfunctional HR department who always sides with the manager or supervisor. Even if you are clearly in the right and it is acknowledged (by HR) they will do nothing to support you or help you out of the negative environment. You are basically forced out of your job. I was told I just had to "deal" with it or move on.

pros: SCH has a strong mission for improving the lives of their patients and families.  Salaries are very good and they subsidize public transportation.
cons: At the management level, politics and poor interdepartmental relationships have caused a very toxic environment. There is no strategic business plan, and as a result, projects are very slow to move forward, if at all.   It is very disappointing to have been driven to work here by the mission of SCH only to discover that behind the scenes those values do nothing to drive the business.   My department has a very high turnover rate.

review_title: Good Place to Work, Dedicated to Children
pros: Salary and benefits.   Culture that is in support of the children and their families.  Good people work here.
cons: Some micro-management of employees without giving clear advance direction.  Given the scope and quality of mid level management work that I provided, I was often given picky, very minor criticisms of myself or my staff so that I felt my boss didn't have enough to do. I'm not a micro-manager so this conflicted with my style.  I prefer a reward system for good employees.

review_title: I have enjoed working here - when it comes to moving up in yuor role it is hard to find the support needed.
pros:
Good company mission 
I like telling people where I work
You know that you are a part of something bigger that is doing a lot of good for a lot of people in the community
cons:
Not a lot of opportunities for Growth. 
HR is difficult and not responsive to concerns. 
Salary is not completive 
Not a lot of vacation time. PTO is calculated in a very confusing nature
Not Many soft perks with the company – if you are not able to take a bus to work parking is very expensive.
culture varies a lot from one department to another - it all comes back to mamagement.

job_title: Direct Service Provider in Seattle, WA
pros: Excellent pediatric care and resources available to children and families; ongoing continuing education and training available, high expectations for all disciplines to provide the best care to children and families, always challenging work as care requirements increase and adapt to new evidence
cons: difficult to obtain supportive work resources including a team of related disciplines to address the heavy workload with children with many special health care needs and their families; new evidence for care and ongoing technology changes requires planned and protected time to learn and reinforce work patterns which is not reliably offered

pros: The organization name draws in very kind people who want to do good work.  Most managers are very supportive of work life balance.
cons:
There is a strong culture that does not enforce accountability. Initiatives will be launched, with people just saying "no" they wont do it. This leaves most areas scattered with some staff following the initiatives and others not. 

Secondly, there is lack of role clarity for most jobs. Most employee's on-boarding involves the 'sink or swim' technique of jumping in without direction. There are no clear guidelines given as to what success looks like, and gaps in what is handled because it is 'someone elses job to do it.' You could ask dozens of people with the same job title what they do- and get a dozen different answers. This leaves people lost and confused about whether they are doing the work they should be doing-- let alone disappointed with performance evaluations

job_title: Human Resources Assistant  in Seattle, WA
pros: It feels good to know you're making a difference, even in non-clinical positions.  All employees, from physicians to custodians, seem to enjoy their work.  Benefits are excellent compared to most hospitals in the region.  While fraught with beauracracy, Children's seems to have their heart in the right place.
cons: It's not located near the center of the city, and there's always construction going on, making navigating the campus a chore.  Due to several shake-ups in upper administration, it seems like Children's mission and vision statements also need a revision to point out their haphazard expansion and growth plans. Also, smells like bleach everywhere.

review_title: Great organization, though certain departments need help.
pros:
The organization helps save children's lives and meanwhile helps nurture families going through the huge challenge of having a sick child. 
Being a part of the organization definitely gave me pride in working there.
Cool new buildings and generally friendly staff.
cons: There is not much attention payed to the back-end offices, which makes sense- they are there to serve their patients, not their employees, but that causes not the best working environments behind the scenes. Poor office space, untidy file room (with visible dust in the air) and poor management with a lot of red tape to cross to get the simplest tasks requested (like thorough dusting).

pros: Love the environment and the drive for always putting patients first. Also they pay pretty fairly and better than other places in the area. I really enjoy the work I do and feel important.
cons: Not many opportunites to change current processes. Are not very flexible with work and life balance, and the parking/commuting can be very stressful. If you don't need to drive to work and don't have to be home at a certain time than you are fine!

pros: Great mission, brand new CEO who seems incredibly genuine and willing to treat employees at all levels with respect and kindness, and SOME departments are filled with wonderful, collaborative, mission driven individuals and managers. If you end up in a great department (which I finally have) your employment experience will live up to the outward perception of the organization.
cons: Parking charges are ridiculous for a residential neighborhood ($10/day). If you waste hours of your life taking the bus rather than parking you get a $4 commute bonus which seems too small. No meaningful training for managers. Lots of people manage staff that have obviously not be trained to mange people. Patronizing attitude among some mid level managers. One manager who earns close to $200k/year and gets a bonus on top of that tried to make me feel like I should be grateful for my $0.54/hr raise.... The bonus structure varies through out the organization. The yearly bonus for most staff ends up being only $300 or $500 and taxes are taken from that. Basically your bonus goes straight to paying for parking. Some mangers like to remind employees of their elevated position by treating hourly staff like children who aren't qualified to have an opinion on the company's business. Lack of transparency. Every decision seems to be made under a shroud of secrecy. Need more staff to keep up with technological demands of the organization. Many managers seems to be more worried about their personal success over the success of the organization or team. I have seen individuals throw others "under the bus" by spreading false information for their own benefit.

job_title: Clinical Research Associate in Seattle, WA
pros: Nice new downtown office building, parking available for $12/day if needed, the view from the rooftop deck
cons: Unpredictable management, little to no on the job training, disconnection with the clinic as research staff, very poor communication

pros: Many opportunities for career development whether it be within your current career direction or in a completely different direction. Gave me flexibility on hours and opportunities to work 4 tens.
cons: You cannot park on campus, so parking or busing and taking shuttles add a lot of time to a commute if you do not live close by. PTO benefits could be better

review_title: Depends on where you work at Children's
pros: Pretty good health insurance, fair pay (very poor raises, though).  Some very nice people work there.  Hard to think of any other positives!
cons: The management in my group was CRAZY -- and on its way down.  Children's as an entity puts policy above the needs of their employees.  Management is GENEROUSLY compensated, but cares very little for those attempting to support them.  Traffic to the downtown locations is horrific.  A lot of pressure to conform: no room for inspiration.  Tons of "politics" in my group.  Micromanagement.

review_title: Don't trust Human Resources for anything
pros: Benefits, child care, ok salaries.
cons: Good salaries = lazy apathetic employees. Good people seem to leave and lazy minimal effort employees seem to stay.

review_title: The blah blah of the mission it is more about the outside perception
pros: Good benefits particularly if you want an excellent health coverage. Some benefits for transportation.
cons: Mediocre pay, old boy club. No opportunity for advancement. Too much focusing on appearance so donors think it is a great mission. Waste of money and obsess with CPI, without changing the embedded culture of mediocre managers. They do not listen. It obsess with security constant problems with , making it difficult to work at times.  Too many hoops to jump to have things done. Internal bureaucracy entrenched

pros: Helping patients and patient families.
cons:
No maternity leave
Stagnant wages
Not allowed to park on campus unless doctor or leadership
Parking off campus is expensive and time consuming
No educational opportunities
Human Resources supports policies not employees
Lack of accountability

review_title: Great for the children; not so great for the employees.
pros:
Great mission with staff dedicated to the wonderful children.
Financially supportive of alternate modes of commute/transportation.
cons: Dysfunctional and sometimes hostile work environment while management professes to be supportive of staff.

review_title: It has been a very posititive and uplifting experience.
pros: A great place to start your career with the option for advancement if you chose.
cons: Parking is an issue and costly if you drive even though they provide off site parking you still have to pay.  If you take the bus you get a bonus but not everyone lives close to a bus line that they don't have to leave their house 1.5- 2 hrs before they start work and then look at the same time to commute back home.  Makes for a very long day.

review_title: CPI everywhere, yet tons of waste
pros:
Good Health Insurance
Free Bus Pass and $4/day bonus for using alternative transportation
The company wants to be lean, but sometimes it is too lean in different departments, and too robust in others
cons:
Mediocre Pay
Lack of flexibility in schedule
Poor Leadership- Too many levels
They don't trim the fat(non performing/poorly performing employees)
Don't reward hard working employees appropriately (small increases in salary)

pros: Room for some career development or growth (in terms of functionality and purpose), job autonomy, very good benefits, overall great culture in the hospital that is pushed, the institution's resources are easy to navigate, HR is very friendly and helpful, good work-life balance is my experience, amazing staff/clinician relationships built in my experience
cons: Though room for growth exists- ancillary roles to do not incur a great compensation bump ("growth" can equal a ton of additional responsibilities without a great pay to compensate= burnout or low morale), overall low salary ranges (compared to other non-for-profit organizations), culture can feel restrictive and "stuffy" in some departments (especially for roles in lower of hierarchy/ancillary positions)

job_title: Medical Laboratory Technologist in Seattle, WA
pros: Children's has a well thought out culture and set of values. They actively strive to build a sense of community that naturally spills over into respective departments. This is reflected in the laboratory, where the team works extremely well together in a positive environment. The hospital and laboratory promotes career growth and continuing education, and there is always room to add your voice to promote improvements. The benefits and salary are excellent, an the work is fulfilling.
cons: Career advancement within the hospital seems like it would take some time from a lab tech perspective; although there are plenty of lateral opportunities or ways to take on additional responsibility to advance yourself professionally.

review_title: Good collegial atmosphere, limited opportunity for advancement in this field.
pros: Cheerful surroundings; outstanding, smart, capable people; fun perks; good benefits.
cons: Too many levels of management, and middle managers have historically been responsible for too many departments (ie spread too thin) which are often competing for scarce resources. Some recent reshuffling has improved this. Too much reliance on metrics and not enough understanding what many providers actually do. So much of what we do is not billable.

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Seattle, WA
pros:
-the scientists
-valuable and meaningful work 
-compensation
cons:
-random "at will" firings of leaders with no explanation 
-disingenuous former core manager who seems to be all talk and cares  more about the bottom line
-eroding benefits package
-nonexistent professional development

pros:
Excellent employees providing excellent care
Good pay and benefits
Teaching facility - provides lots of learning opportunities
Emphasis on diversity both in hiring and how to best serve an increasingly diverse Pacific NW community
cons:
Since Children's started underwriting its own insurance benefits, out of pocket expenses for employees have increased.
Work-life balance: It is getting more and more expensive to live within the Seattle city limits. With traffic or using "alternate" forms of transportation, it can make for a very long day, especially if one is working a 12 hr shift. 
Employees suffering from change-fatigue.

review_title: Good mission, great benefits, twisted way of treating employees
job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in Seattle, WA
pros: Great benefits, especially if you have children. Free loaner bikes if you want to bike commute. Free ORCA card, commute bonus, and all the branded pens you could ever want.
cons: Screwy way of dealing with employees. For example: facilities one day went into the locker rooms and cleared out all the personal effects not in locked lockers and threw them away. No ability to claim items. I personally lost $60 worth of items. A co-worker lost $200 of bike gear. No apologies given, no compensation for lost items. We were basically told to stuff it. They pull crap like that all the time.

review_title: Working at CHildren's has great benefits but good deeds are not always recognized.
job_title: Clinical Research Associate  in Seattle, WA
pros: Great place to work!  It has a wonderful atmosphere and the people are hardworking, ethical, and genuine.
cons: Good works can sometimes go unrecognized, and compensation compared to regional standards doesn't quite add up, but the benefits are amazing, so it evens out in the long run.

job_title: Surgical Coordination Specialist in Seattle, WA
pros: Feeling like you are making a difference in patients and families lives. Very supportive medical staff who encourage learning. The fact that Children's is a teaching hospital, there is always an opportunity to learn new things everyday.
cons: Horrible work/life balance. Terrible vacation benefits. No sick time available for hourly and you have to use your accrued PTO for recognized holidays you couldn't work anyway.

pros:
-Excellent clinicians
-Patient centered 
-Transportation Incentives
cons:
-Lack of transparency from management
-High turnover
-Hostile work environment
-Hypocrisy
-Poor work-life balance

review_title: Great, if you're not one of the little people.
job_title: Certified Nursing Assistant in Seattle, WA
pros:
-benefits, paid 100% for you and your children when working 24+ hrs/week
-6 weeks paid maternity leave
-depending on department, flexible scheduling as long as you fulfill your every other weekend commitment. 
-high morale and a generally happy place to work
-although prices to park on campus are fairly high, you are provided with many, many alternatives (approx. $10 for weekday shifts, and lower for evening, night, and weekend shifts, as well as the rate split in half if you carpool) there are also plenty of shuttles that run from popular bus routes in the city/light rail to the main campus that make commuting a bit more manageable, and an incentive of $4 per shift that you commute to work In any way other than driving yourself in, as well as a discounted ORCA card.. A few dollars taken from your paycheck covers the cost. You may opt out if you'd like. 
-company seems to encourage managers to hire within the hopsital
cons:
As a CNA, not every unit offers 12 hr shifts. So if you work full time night shift, you are here 10 out of 14 nights a pay period, with a requirement of every other weekend worked. This is very hard for personal, family, and social life. I left for a 12 hour unit as soon as I hit my 6months. 
- I felt like my position is a thankless one. Often feels as if we are treated as second class to the RNs and replaceable. 
-compensation is higher here than most adult family homes and retirement communities, but still seems low for the amount of work we do as CNA's. Most admin positions start out at least $1.50 more base pay.

review_title: Cutting edge in the field of pediatric medicine and health care.
job_title: Patient Scheduler for Clinic in Seattle, WA
pros: It's an amazing environment for young people who are chronically ill. Each child is treated with the highest level of care that is holistic and creative in every aspect of their visit to the hospital. No child is ever denied the quality of service that is second to none. The entire staff is held to a standard of quality that can only be described as top notch.
cons: The ratio of people of color to whites, in the higher positions of authority are poorly under represented.  The office culture seems more corporate  rather than non-profit.

pros: It can be hard to get in, but once you are in you are in.
cons: It is a who you know organization. The organization preaches that they want to be competitive with salaries for staff, but know their first offer is usually 80% of market average. Never accept their first offer. Contractors make substantially more than staff in the same position and when they are brought on they sometimes are given much higher titles than their experience merits due to their compensation demands.

review_title: Highest mission and purpose, backwards management politics
job_title: Research Manager, Project Manager in Seattle, WA
pros: The mission is the obvious gem - it's incredibly gratifying to help kids and families. I loved telling people I worked there. There was evident enterprise-wide interest in employee engagement. The benefits were great, especially the health coverage. There were a variety of growth paths, and training opportunities.
cons: Management was focused on the appearance of rather than the substance of compliance, excellence, and transparency. Clear old boys club in upper management. Definite cultural divide and power imbalance between MDs (who can be abusive and above the rules) and other caregivers or administrators.

review_title: Children's is great if you can adapt to their culture.
pros: Nice place to work for with some nice perks like a commute bonus and a Orca card.

Upper management needs to have better communication with the employees.
There is a lot of distrust and they make it hard for outsiders to feel like they are part of the team if you don't think exactly like them.
If they don't like you they will do whatever they can to push you out. 
Not much room for growth or advancement.

review_title: Great mission, incompetent management, little professional growth, absolutely awful experience
pros:
Great mission
Top-notch medical experts providing comprehensive, compassionate patient care
Excellent researchers doing critical work to finding cures for childhood diseases
Facility is child and family friendly
cons:
Upper management is a good ol' boys club.
Many administrative management staff is non-effective and have risen to the position due to years at the company rather than talent to do the job - the barnacle effect.
Opportunity for advancement and career development is lacking. 
Administrative management falls down on the job setting an example of "ART - Accountability Respect & Teamwork"

pros: fantastic benefits package, good PTO, discount perks, working for a company you can be proud of, great work environment, friendly staff, full prorated benefits from 30 hours on
cons: having to pay to park on or off campus, having to occasionally work 6-7 days a week and not hit 40 hours a week, no cost of living wage increase relying only on "performance" review to close the gap

job_title: Grant and Contract Administrator in Seattle, WA
pros: This place respects all levels of work and encourages participation by all.  All ideas are considered, not just ideas from the top.  Flexible work environment and schedule making work life balance flawless.  Good benefits, including the commuter bonus and bike program. Flexible PTO to customize holidays meaningful to you.  Free employee Shuttle system to facilitate easy access between the main hospital, UW, and the research institute in downtown.
cons: Pay could be better, but the no stress environment more than makes up for it.

pros:
Work/life balance
Environment is rewarding to work in
Friendly staff
Starbucks on site
Decent pay
Commuter bonus

Depending on which department you work in, it can be a little bit isolating and not enough exposure to the hospital/patients, you often forget you work in a hospital

Vacation/Sick time is pooled together and takes sometime to accumulate. Also holidays are taking from your PTO pool

review_title: Family Service Coordinator in Speciality Clinic
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros:
The overall vibe is that most employees really care about the families they work with. 

Talented doctors
cons:
The organization makes horrible management and dept. changes without asking the opinions of employees, ie bringing in a new manager and new supervisor that don't understand the specialized clinic needs and demands. 

Pay does not reflect the workload.

review_title: Overall, a great organization to work for.
pros:
Good employee incentives and discounts. Very dedicated to continuous process improvement.
Benefits are great, if you get them!
cons:
Constantly increasing workload without additional FTE to support it. 
Do not give per diem employees benefits even if they're working 40 hrs/wk every week. Also does not give bonus pay in lieu of benefits like most other companies.
They may fire you for little to no reason. HR is quick to make assumptions and doesn't care what your side of the story is.

job_title: Animal Care Operations Coordinator in Seattle, WA
pros: Great benefits, opportunities for advanced training, ie: minor surgery.
cons: Lots of hours, no overtime, looked down upon by supervisors and upper management.  Very little care for employees or amount of time is required by employees.  I can be paid to overlook the extreme overtime requirement, but the job is salary with no overtime.  Once I was promised a bonus by the lab supervisor for my hard work and long hours, never received it.

pros: Great co-workers, who are committed to the mission and vision.  Finding someone who believes in your talent and helps you find your place.
cons: Co-workers who think they are better than you because their title has a higher pay grade.  Upper management who write about their commitment to the staff, but come across as aloof in person.

pros:
The collaborative culture along with the innovative spirit
Helping Kids and Families
Great co-workers who care about the work they do
Excellent benefits
Emphasis on public transit and the free bus pass + commuter bonus makes it easy to do the right thing
cons:
Non-profits have challenges with matching industry salaries
Distance between hospital and research campus means travel to some meetings takes more time than I'd like
Not the best IT infrastructure can be a challenge at times

pros: Everyone rallies around the mission. Lots of dedicated staff. Smart people and great clinical care. Opportunities for career development and very well respected in community.
cons: Lots of changes in leadership-which is a good thing but at times old guard and new guard at odds. At times feels like the organization needs to get with the times in terms of benefits, telecommuting, parking and pay.

review_title: Great mission but IT professionals beware
pros: The mission is by far the best you will ever be part of.  I truly believe the organization’s heart is in the right place and the clinical staff do amazing things despite the organizational, staffing and technical challenges they are forced to navigate.
cons:
IT Leadership is laughably bad.  With the introduction of a new CIO, the IT organization has gone from a slow, bloated band of retirement short timers with some guiding principals to the CIO’s personal ego-laden cruise ship navigating the North Atlantic with a first mate and navigator who have never sailed anything larger than a dingy and no one on watch for the inevitable ice burgs.

The new CIO has shown a propensity toward unethical actions.  He seems incapable of decision making and delegates everything that requires any thoughtful analysis to his C-level henchmen.  The C-Level IT leadership can’t seem to get past their bloated egos for any level of self awareness.

The entire IT organization has quickly become completely devoid of direction.  The only focus is cutting cost and moving to a consolidated medical records system which seems to be the bullit item the CIO needs for his resume.  He expounds customer obsession, but has done nothing to enable the organization to deliver. 

From an overall IT perspective, Architecture is nonexistent, filled with sysadmins and network technicians.  The Program Management Office has been dissolved and has turned into a project management free-for-all with no prioritization.  Infrastructure has been gutted of leadership.  Application teams are chasing their tails and duplicating effort.  Operations leadership has no operations experience.  IT finance is completely out of touch with the requirements of running an IT organization.  There is literally no aspect of IT that is running well under the new leadership.

The new CIO has said in meetings that “HR won’t let me fire who I want so I will just have to make it so uncomfortable that they will leave”.  And leaving they are.  With the notable loss of the CISO, everyone of technical substance is working on an exit strategy.  

If you are considering a role in IT with Seattle Children’s Hospital, you should reconsider.  Things here are going to get much, much worse before they get better.

review_title: Awesome research institute  to work for!
pros: I love the people that I work with, and all the benefits that comes with the job.  Research institute on Stewart and Ninth is very new and is very clean. They also encourage commuting via public transportation and give us monetary bonuses for using public transportation (which is paid for in the first place).
cons: The management is not very structured in some labs. I also do not like the very short window for delivered package pick up.

pros: Great Place to work! They truly care about their employees.Magnet certified. As a CNA you are able to learn a great deal and gain a lot of experience. Everyone that works there truly loves working for Seattle children's.
cons: As a CNA your pay raise is based on your performance each year and does not increase any more than .45 on your hourly pay.

job_title: Certified Athletic Trainer in Seattle, WA
pros: As an employee I received a great benefits package and great pay for my experience. The work environment was very welcoming and the organization took good care of their employees, offering health and wellness resources to balance work and personal life.
cons: My department would pick of last minute contracts often and it felt like we were forced to work a lot of last minute events which made it hard to balance work an personal life sometimes.

job_title: Summer Camp Assistant in Seattle, WA
pros: The transportation itself was great. I loved the people there and although I wished I could have seen Russell Wilson, he was on the opposite wing of me.
cons: All I can say is the distance.  Depending on how far away you are.  I can't really say alot about cons.  Except to do really well at your job.

job_title: Nurse Educator (Unit Based Educator) in Seattle, WA
pros:
Great "can-do" attitude about improvements that could lead to safer care provision and increased employee satisfaction.
Lots of opportunities to get more involved in process improvement or other projects.
Great atmosphere
Great internal job posting culture (you can get a completely new job and stay in the organization and you're more likely to get hired if you apply internally)
cons: I really can't think of many. There are limited food options for night shift workers and since we are a 24/7 facility, this seems a little silly.

pros: Able to work with families and children. Are able to make a positive impact on families. Friendly and cooperative atmosphere. Great place for growth in career.
cons: Some of the downsides of working at Seattle Children's is the location. Lack of quality pay for undergraduate students. It is difficult to support oneself if this is primary job.

pros:
This is by far one of the most amazing institutions out there. The hospital, foundation and research institute are one-of-a-kind. 

I felt like I worked with family when I was employed here.
cons: They hire people who are over qualified for their positions and then expect them to stay when they can't promote them. The pay is not always fair.

review_title: Old boys network in IT Management
pros: Coworkers are great, mission is great. The front-line workers are working really hard to make a difference to the kids who need it. There are a lot of smart, caring people working here that contribute to the mission of the organization.
cons: IT is run by a former Air Force team, and the culture really changed for the worse when they came on. Old boys network at the top in IT, no room for advancement if you were not part of that.

job_title: Citrix Engineer I in Seattle, WA
pros: Great coworkers, very knowledgeable.  Excellent place to work, and they are helping make the city a better place.
cons: Management team does not understand the existing systems. Teams are so badly in silos that multiple teams are using different versions of network monitoring software. Some coworkers are just there to collect paychecks, and management is not able to remove these characters.

pros:
You will never be bored  the milleu is always changing and interesting but also stressful.
The department head, Ann Moore, is an amazing, no-nonsense leader who is highly respected by all.
cons:
Young staff with little empathy for patients or ability to see big picture.  
Target for bullying if you ask too many questions from both peers and RN staff.

pros: Great benefits, semi-urban location, fantastic telecommuting options, located right on the Burke-Gilman trail, cutting edge pediatric research, rated #32 by Forbes Magazine for Top 500 Best Places to Work!
cons: On-site parking can be expensive for employees, laptops not provided to all employees,

Opportunities for advancement are limited and salaries are dictated by arbitrary parameters rather than merit. No in the same scale for similar industry, way below averages.

review_title: This is an amazing company that I am proud to be a part of
job_title: Family Services Representative in Seattle, WA
pros: Children's is an incredibly diverse environment to work in. Every day brings a fresh  perspective on life and a new lesson about people.

review_title: We are so spoiled as employees
job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in Seattle, WA

cons: Unfortunately this organization is driven by the principles of empire building and CYA like many others.  With 200% bi-annual turnover in departmental staff it drags their commitment to excellence on the care side of the house more difficult.  Vision is excellent, execution is lacking.

pros: Seattle Children's is a great hospital.  People are good to you just because you work there.  This opens a lot of doors.

cons: The contact center can sometimes feel like it's micromanaged as "numbers" are one of the top priorities. But at the same time, management is good with making you feel seen and valued.

pros: I enjoyed working with children, and much wanted the experience when I left It was to further my education.

Excellent management

Beautiful facility and well maintained gardens outside.
Up to date with most current practices.

review_title: Excellent place to work;  incredible employer with an incredible mission.

cons: A handful of employees are not sufficiently motivated to contribute.

pros: Great staff! Excellent coworkers. Competitive Salary. Room for advancement. Clinical and advanced education opportunities available. Affordable health care. Management listens and cares. Proud to be an employee.

cons: For PRN staff they have minimum work requirements.  Its hard to make ends meet on their salaries.  Seattle is extremely expensive and their wages could use an adjustment.
